definition[0]: the place in the ground where a dead body is buried
example[0]: At the head of the grave there was a small wooden cross.
example[1]: In the churchyard, a man was digging a grave.
example[2]: The stone marked the grave of their young daughter.
example[3]: She was buried in a grave next to her older sister.
example[4]: They found the woman’s remains in a shallow grave in the woods.
example[5]: Plague victims were buried in a mass grave.
example[6]: Until 1855, poor people here were buried in unmarked graves.
example[7]: Walter died in 1922 and was buried in the family grave in Finchley cemetery.
example[8]: He wept by her open grave.
example[9]: The president visited the grave sites of 12 youths killed in recent bombings.
definition[1]: grave problems, situations, or worries are very great or bad
example[10]: Matthew’s life is in grave danger.
example[11]: The report expressed grave concern over the technicians’ lack of training.
example[12]: I have grave doubts about his ability.
example[13]: The situation is becoming very grave.
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people usually use serious  rather than grave, and seriously rather than gravely:
example[14]: I have serious doubts about whether he’s up to the job.
definition[2]: looking or sounding quiet and serious, especially because something important or worrying has happened
example[16]: Turnbull’s face was grave as he told them about the accident.
definition[3]: a grave accent is a mark put above a letter in some languages such as French to show the pronunciation, for example è
